Award.AwardTitle: Developing Computational Thinking by Creating Multi-player Physically Active Math Games

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Our nation's economy is rapidly shifting. Both educators and business leaders recognize that computational thinking (CT) is a "new basic" knowledge necessary for economic opportunity and social mobility. All students should have the opportunity to learn computational thinking in school and be prepared with computational skills that they can apply in almost every discipline. Computational thinking skills include problem solving, systems thinking, computational modeling and data practices. This project uses cell phone technology to train middle school students in public schools in computational thinking and mathematics. Students will learn to create augmented reality games with math challenges. This new genre of embodied technologies that use mobile devices, motion and physical activity will allow middle-school learners to create their own augmented reality math games and play each other's math games. The research intends to advance scientific knowledge on how people learn by investigating how to teach mathematics and computing through game design and game-based learning. K-12 students will learn to program mobile devices as finite-state-machines, a topic that is typically reserved for undergraduates in computer science. In this process, students shift their perspective from consumers of technology to producers, understand what is beneath and beyond the surface of what they can immediately see and perceive, and think at higher levels of abstraction, an important computational skill.

The project continues the development of The Wearable Learning Cloud Platform (WLCP), a learning technology innovation started with an earlier NSF EAGER award. The Game Editor of this platform supports students as creators of math games while gaining computational thinking skills. Research studies will evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention, the professional development structure, and the game creation process as a vehicle to develop computational thinking and mathematical thinking for both students and their teachers. Research will address three research questions focused on students' and teachers' development of computational thinking, engagement, interest, self-concept, and on teachers' instructional practices: (1) How feasible is it for middle school students to create embodied multiplayer math games, exercising their computational thinking and deep mathematical thinking in the process? What are challenges faced and how should middle school students be supported? (2) In what ways do students improve computational thinking and deepen their math understanding as they create embodied math games? (3) Can teachers effectively implement the math game creation curriculum and help students improve CT? Researchers will develop an instrument to measure students' progression in computational thinking skills. Research methods also include observations, teacher reflections, artifacts from classroom implementation, and semi-structured interviews. These measures will generate valuable data about students' and teachers' learning processes while creating their games and programming wearables. The outcome of the project will advance our knowledge in how youth learn math and gain computational skills through physically active games using mobile technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT.

This project investigated how to promote Computational Thinking in middle school students by engaging them in the design of mobile and wearable Learning Technologies for Mathematics. It evaluated how the process of ideating embodied (physically active) technologies influence student's Computational Thinking. Specifically, the project investigated the role of mobile technologies in enhancing students' Computational Thinking skills and their capacity for innovation through embodied, collaborative games within the realms of Computer Science and Computational Thinking. 

This award supported students in designing and programming mathematics games aimed for their peer classmates to use. The WearableLearning platform, developed as part of this award, provided a drag-and-drop programming interface for creating these multiplayer math games. These games, inspired by playground activities that are natural to students (e.g. Tag, Capture the Flag, Scavenger Hunts, Ball Games) involve each student carrying or wearing a mobile device (e.g., smartphone or tablet) as they play these math games, typically in team-based formats. This project also involved iterative enhancements to the platform's infrastructure to support both the creation and play of these game-like math activities.

The WearableLearning Platform, accessible at wearablelearning.org, is a web service system that connects to each player's mobile device. Students program the coordinated behavior of multiple devices from a "Game Editor" --a specialized programming environment that supports debugging and coordination, enabling rich, multi-player social interactions, as well as interactions with objects (e.g. mathematical objects).

Research studies conducted over the course of the project revealed that, after 8-10 hours of engagement with the WearableLearning curriculum and platform, middle school students demonstrated significant improvement in two aspects of Computational Thinking: Algorithmic Thinking/Computational Problem Solving and Modeling/Simulation practices. This progress was evident in their work, as they developed more sophisticated game models and honed their debugging skills. Further follow-up studies have shown that both middle and early high school students, after exposure to the WearableLearning curriculum and platform, experience increased self-efficacy in computer programming and a stronger sense of their ability to innovate.

BROADER IMPACTS.

Children have a natural inclination for movement, generally preferring active hands-on curriculum over sitting at desks. The WearableLearning technology offers a promising approach to engage students who are highly active and those who tend to become disengaged from STEM subjects as they progress through school. Despite the challenges posed by COVID, this research has positively impacted a diverse range of students. Hundreds of students from afterschool programs and summer camps from school districts with a high percentage of underrepresented minorities, have benefited from this initiative.

Additionally, around 25 teachers have participated in Professional Development sessions focused on Computational Thinking and WearableLearning. These teachers have not only piloted the WearableLearning curriculum in their classrooms but also contributed significantly by designing about half of the math games featured under our "Flagship games" section of the website.

We have actively shared the goals, ideas, and ongoing progress of this research on embodied games and Computational Thinking with the research community. To further support teachers and students, we have developed comprehensive online Professional Development resources, including videos, instructional guides, materials, and an online PD course on WearableLearning. These resources enable both teachers and students not only to play, but especially to learn how to use WearableLearning to create their own multiplayer, physically-active games.
